page.title: 01THE COUNTRY W. CHESELBOURNE
page.content: From where the village of Cheselbourne (a mixture of traditional thatched cottages and more modern houses and bungalows) ends in the north, the countryside to the east becomes hilly farmland occasionally covered by deciduous woods and copses. The whole area is bissected from east to west by a minor road from which several tracks lead off into the countryside. A small tributary of the River Piddle flows from north to south in the centre of the area and there are four major farms. Several Tumuli (9 in all) are dotted across the landscape and in the north west the terrain forms an unusual horeseshoe shaped valley with sheep, partially wooded slopes at Lyscombe bottom. Though the areas main industry is farming a construction company (Okeford Construction) has its headquarters located on the northern
